title: blackletter - sydney morning herald
content:
![](http://web.archive.org/web/20080103050612im_/http:/www.typophile.com/files/300px-Sydney_morning_herald_masthead_4380.png)

Searching for the actual or something similar.

I find typeIDing blackletters so much more difficult :/

 [‹ Waves of Change / Free & Easy ~ Surf movie posters](http://web.archive.org/web/20080103050612/http:/www.typophile.com/node/27924 "Go to previous forum topic") [Help! What font is that? ›](http://web.archive.org/web/20080103050612/http:/www.typophile.com/node/27648 "Go to next forum topic")
author: noftus

comments.content:
The lettering of tough to identify newspaper namplates is almost all custom drawn, especially the blacklettered examples.

What about [Agincourt](http://web.archive.org/web/20080103050612/http:/www.linotype.com/11625/agincourtplain-font.html), or [Mariage](http://web.archive.org/web/20080103050612/http:/www.linotype.com/89949/mariageregular-font.html)? Neither are exact matches, but I doubt that there is an exact match.

It’s funny that Linotype changed the name of ’Linotext’ to ’Mariage’. I wonder when that name change was done. Any idea Dan?

As their writep mentions, it has been known by a ’plethora of names’, but [’Wedding Text’](http://web.archive.org/web/20080103050612/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/bitstream/wedding-text/) is probably the best known, and is the original name of the Morris Fuller Benton typeface from 1901.

- Mike Yanega

Linotext’s name has NOT been changed. We have two typefaces based off of Wedding Text, Mariage and Linotext.

Here is the link to Linotext:  
 [http://www.linotype.com/948/linotext-family.html](http://web.archive.org/web/20080103050612/http:/www.linotype.com/948/linotext-family.html "http://www.linotype.com/948/linotext-family.html")

Linotext is a slightly lighter font than Mariage, which feels like a slightly darker digitization to me. I recommeded Mariage in this case only because its slightly greater dense-ness seems closer to the Syndey Morning Herald’s nameplate than Linotext does.
As a side note, Linotype has been distributing “Linotext” since about 1926. I don’t know where Mariage came from, or in what year or format it first entered the Linotype Library.

Thanks Dan for the correction on that. I thought Mariage looked slightly condensed, but I jumped to the wrong conclusion that it was the same font with a new name.

- Mike Yanega

It could be a bit more condensed, I’ve never set them side by side. Every digitizer uses different masters for their designs… Wedding Text may have had differences depending on its various point sizes.
